questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a whistling sound during respiration for the past 3 weeks. He reports that the whistling is becoming louder, and is especially loud when he exercises. He says the noise is frustrating for him. Two months ago, the patient underwent outpatient treatment for an uncomplicated nasal fracture after being hit in the nose by a high-velocity stray baseball. Since the accident, the patient has been taking aspirin for pain. He has a history of asymptomatic nasal polyps. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following would have prevented the whistling during respiration?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nasal septal perforation may develop as a sequela of septal hematoma secondary to a nasal fracture. The hematoma disrupts blood flow to the septal cartilage, resulting in ischemia, necrosis, and subsequent perforation. Analgesics with antiplatelet activity such as aspirin should be avoided 48 hours after nasal trauma or surgery as they may precipitate the development of septal hematoma. This patient's prolonged pain after nasal injury may also be a sign of complications such as nasal hematoma and perforation. If a nasal septal hematoma is present, aspiration and drainage should be performed immediately to reduce pressure on the cartilage and prevent complications.

Whistling typically resolves with the placement of a silicone button prosthesis.
Image Description:

Bilateral, firm, balloon-like swelling of the nasal mucosa.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the patient has a history of nasal polyps, polyp resection is unlikely to have prevented the whistling. Surgical removal of nasal polyps is only indicated if the patient is symptomatic and a trial with topical or systemic glucocorticoids is unsuccessful. Symptomatic nasal polyps typically manifest with a postnasal drip, bilateral nasal obstruction, and frequently hyposmia or anosmia; their presence is not associated with a whistling sound.
Image Description:

CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane) of patient with history of asthma

Extensive soft tissue opacification of the ethmoid sinuses (E; outline) and nasal cavity (NC; outline) shows some lobulation (black arrowhead) and evidence of bony erosion (dashed outline). Lobulated soft tissue is also present along the maxillary sinus walls (white arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy in combination with incision and drainage is indicated in patients with septal abscess. A septal abscess most commonly develops secondary to a septal hematoma (e.g., due to a facial trauma, as seen in this patient) and can also lead to septal perforation. However, septal abscess is a rare complication of nasal injury and would usually manifest with nasal swelling and obstruction, which this patient does not report.

D) INCORRECT:

Rhinoplasty may be performed for aesthetic or functional reasons, such as obstructed breathing due to congenital nasal deformities or trauma. However, rhinoplasty is not indicated for the prevention of nasal septal perforation and may even cause the condition if septal hematoma occurs postoperatively.

E) INCORRECT:

Septoplasty is indicated to correct nasal septum deviation in patients with pronounced clinical findings such as difficulty breathing, headaches, or facial pain. Septoplasty is also used in the treatment of nasal septal perforation, but it is not used in the prevention thereof. As septoplasty may precipitate the development of septal hematoma, it can in fact contribute to subsequent septal perforation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a nasal whistling sound 2 months after sustaining a nasal fracture, suggesting nasal septal perforation.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents with worsening nasal congestion and concern that he may have broken his nose. Three days ago, he was hit in the nose by a baseball and experienced immediate epistaxis, which subsequently resolved. Ibuprofen has been used for pain control.
On examination, the child notes significant pain of the face, but there is no crepitus or step-off noted upon palpation. There is moderate edema of the nasal dorsum with bruising but no visible deviation. Examination of the nose internally reveals fullness of the septum bilaterally. The turbinates are difficult to visualize. There is copious rhinorrhea.
What is the best next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Reassurance with outpatient follow-up in 7 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal septal hematomas can occur independently of nasal bone fractures and must always be ruled out, even if the examination does not reveal signs of fracture such as step-off or crepitus. The diagnosis of both septal hematomas and nasal fractures is based on physical examination alone and does not require imaging. In this case, imaging would delay incision and drainage, thereby increasing the risk for abscess and cartilage erosion leading to long-term nasal deformity.

B) INCORRECT:

Nasal glucocorticoids and prednisone can be helpful in the management of allergic rhinitis but will not help in this case, and any delay in incision and drainage adds to the risk for pressure necrosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a nasal septal hematoma. This condition classically occurs after blunt-force nasal injury and manifests with nasal pain, unilateral or bilateral fullness of the nasal cavity secondary to the septal fluid collection, and nasal congestion. Bilateral bulging of the septal mucosa with secretions may be seen, and palpation of the area would reveal a fluid collection.

Nasal septal hematomas occur when blood vessels are disrupted in the layer between the cartilage and the perichondrium. Management involves immediate incision and drainage. Otherwise, fluid buildup in the area can lead to pressure necrosis of the cartilage and long-term complications including septal perforation and saddle-nose deformity.

Nasal septal hematomas can occur independently of nasal bone fractures and must always be ruled out, even if the examination does not reveal signs of fracture such as step-off or crepitus. The diagnosis of both septal hematomas and nasal fractures is based on physical examination alone and does not require imaging. In this case, imaging would delay incision and drainage, thereby increasing the risk for abscess and cartilage erosion leading to long-term nasal deformity. In some situations, ultrasonography or CT may be indicated, but these should not be pursued before urgent draining of the hematoma.

Key learning point: Nasal septal hematomas manifest with septal fullness, nasal congestion, and facial pain.
Image Description:

Basal view of the nose

Red, balloon-like swelling of the nasal mucosa (green overlay) is visible on both sides of the nasal septal cartilage.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance with outpatient follow-up will delay care and increase the risk for complications from untreated septal hematoma and abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Nasal glucocorticoids and prednisone can be helpful in the management of allergic rhinitis but will not help in this case, and any delay in incision and drainage adds to the risk for pressure necrosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents after facial trauma during a collision while playing soccer. He has periorbital ecchymosis, numbness over the right cheek extending to the upper lip, and malocclusion when clenching his teeth. Physical examination shows mobility of the hard palate when the maxilla is manipulated. Vital signs are normal, and vision is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain plain radiographs of the face
Order serum lactate and arterial blood gas
Obtain high-resolution CT of the face

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oromaxillofacial surgery consultation is indicated for definitive management of facial fractures, but imaging must be obtained first to characterize the fracture pattern and provide essential information for surgical planning. Early consultation without imaging limits the specialist's ability to properly evaluate injuries and plan treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs (Waters view) may be used when CT is not immediately available, but high-resolution CT is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating complex midfacial fractures. X-rays have limited ability to fully characterize Le Fort fractures and assess associated injuries.

C) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies, including serum lactate and arterial blood gas, are not routinely required for isolated facial fractures in hemodynamically stable patients. These tests would be considered if there were signs of systemic compromise or associated injuries requiring evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- High-resolution CT of the face with thin slices and 3D reconstruction is the preferred imaging modality for suspected midfacial fractures. This patient presents with hard palate mobility (floating palate), dental malocclusion, and infraorbital nerve dysfunction, suggesting a Le Fort fracture pattern. CT imaging is essential to determine the specific type and extent of the fracture before proceeding with further management or specialist consultation.

E) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are not routinely recommended for facial fractures and are only considered for specific indications such as open fractures or fractures breaching sinus walls. Fracture pattern and characteristics must be determined through imaging before deciding about the use of antibiotics.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents after being punched in the jaw during a fight. He reports pain with chewing and states his bite feels "off." Physical examination reveals facial swelling, limited mouth opening to 25 mm, and ecchymosis on the floor of his mouth. Vital signs are stable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform tongue blade bite test and obtain imaging if abnormal
Obtain high-resolution CT face and consult maxillofacial surgery
Start prophylactic antibiotics and arrange follow-up with dentistry
Perform closed reduction and arrange follow-up with primary care
Obtain panoramic radiographs and discharge if normal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The tongue blade bite test can assist clinical judgment if the physical examination is equivocal. This patient already demonstrates clear clinical signs of mandibular fracture (trismus, malocclusion, and floor of mouth ecchymosis following direct trauma to the jaw) that warrant imaging and surgical consultation rather than additional screening tests.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic signs of mandibular fracture, including trismus, malocclusion, and ecchymosis on the floor of the mouth, which is pathognomonic for mandibular fractures. High-resolution CT with 3D reconstruction is the preferred imaging modality for suspected mandibular fractures. Maxillofacial surgery should be consulted for all mandibular fractures to determine appropriate treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with classic signs of mandibular fracture, including trismus, malocclusion, and pathognomonic ecchymosis of the floor of the mouth. While prophylactic antibiotics may be considered for mandibular fractures involving tooth-bearing regions, this approach is premature without confirmatory diagnostic imaging. Additionally, mandibular fractures require a different specialist referral.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of limited mouth opening, malocclusion, and ecchymosis of the floor of the mouth indicates significant injury requiring further evaluation and likely surgical management. Attempting a closed reduction without first ruling out a fracture could cause iatrogenic injury. Additionally, this patient likely needs specialist referral.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with classic signs of mandibular fracture, including trismus, malocclusion, and pathognomonic ecchymosis of the floor of the mouth. Panoramic radiographs have better sensitivity than standard x-rays for mandibular fractures, but x-ray overall has low sensitivity for mandibular fractures. A different diagnostic modality is preferred to avoid missed injuries that need specialist referral.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is a construction worker, presents 6 hours after being struck in the face by a swinging metal pipe. She reports nasal pain and bilateral nasal congestion. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital ecchymosis, epistaxis, and rightward deviation of the nose. Extraocular movements are intact, and there is no palpable step-off deformity of the orbital rim. Internal nasal examination shows a smooth, bluish, balloon-like protrusion from the nasal septum that does not blanch with vasoconstrictor spray. X-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Discharge with otolaryngology follow-up in 5 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal cautery with silver nitrate is used for treating anterior epistaxis when the bleeding site is identified, but it is inappropriate for septal hematomas. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood with intact mucosa that requires surgical drainage, not cautery, which could cause tissue injury and septal necrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge with routine follow-up is inappropriate when a septal hematoma is present. This complication requires urgent specialist consultation and immediate surgical drainage to prevent serious sequelae.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- A smooth, bluish, balloon-like nasal protrusion that does not blanch indicates nasal septal hematoma, which requires immediate surgical drainage to prevent complications including septal perforation, infection, and saddle nose deformity. The hematoma separates cartilage from perichondrium, disrupting nutrient supply, leading to ischemia and necrosis if untreated.

D) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction is inappropriate when a septal hematoma is present, because the hematoma must be drained first. Also, uncomplicated nasal fractures are ideally reduced 5–10 days after injury, once swelling has resolved.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior nasal packing treats epistaxis but does not affect the underlying septal hematoma. Septal hematoma requires surgical drainage, and packing could worsen the obstruction and delay recognition of this complication.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department 2 hours after sustaining a direct blow to the nose during a basketball game. He reports severe bilateral nasal congestion and difficulty breathing through his nose. Physical examination shows swelling and ecchymosis of the nasal bridge. Rhinoscopy shows bilateral smooth, bluish protrusions with intact overlying mucosa, causing near-complete obstruction of the nasal passages. X-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the facial bones

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delayed consultation is inappropriate for septal hematoma, which requires immediate intervention. Cartilage necrosis can begin within hours, and urgent drainage is necessary to prevent permanent nasal deformity and functional impairment.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Bilateral smooth, bluish protrusions with intact mucosa and nasal obstruction indicate nasal septal hematoma. Immediate incision and drainage are required to prevent cartilage necrosis, infection, septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity. Nasal septal hematoma separates cartilage from perichondrium, disrupting oxygen and nutrient supply.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasal decongestants are effective for treating mucosal edema. Bilateral smooth protrusions with intact mucosa and absence of active bleeding indicate septal hematoma, not mucosal edema.

D) INCORRECT:

While CT may eventually be needed to evaluate for fractures in this patient, the most appropriate next step is drainage of the septal hematoma to prevent cartilage necrosis. Urgent surgical intervention is needed before imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior nasal packing is indicated for active epistaxis. This patient has a septal hematoma with intact mucosa and no active bleeding, requiring immediate drainage rather than packing, which could worsen the obstruction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with left cheek pain after falling off her bicycle. Physical examination reveals mild swelling over the left zygomatic arch but no trismus, diplopia, or facial asymmetry. Her visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally with normal extraocular movements. CT shows a nondisplaced left zygomatic arch fracture without involvement of the orbital rim or maxillary walls. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Conservative management with analgesia and observation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Nondisplaced, isolated zygomatic arch fractures without functional impairment can be managed conservatively with analgesia, physical measures (cooling, decongesting nose drops), functional relief (e.g., soft food), and observation. This patient has no trismus, diplopia, facial deformity, or orbital involvement to indicate operative management.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent oromaxillofacial surgery consultation is indicated for displaced fractures, zygomatic arch instability, functional impairment, or zygomaticomaxillary complex fractures. This isolated, nondisplaced zygomatic arch fracture without complications does not require urgent surgical evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are not indicated in the acute management of facial fractures. While corticosteroids may help reduce swelling in some facial fractures, they are not a primary treatment modality for stable, nondisplaced fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency ophthalmology consultation is not indicated in this patient with normal visual acuity, no diplopia, normal extraocular movements, and no orbital involvement on CT imaging. There are no signs of ocular injury requiring ophthalmologic evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction is not appropriate for this patient's nondisplaced fracture. The fracture is already in anatomic position, and this patient has no functional impairment that would warrant reduction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. She has extensive facial swelling, bilateral periorbital ecchymosis, and active oropharyngeal bleeding. The maxilla moves freely when grasped, and there is a palpable step-off at the inferior orbital rim. She has a Glasgow coma scale score of 14. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 98; SpO2, 92% on room air. She is increasingly agitated and has gurgling respirations with difficulty clearing secretions. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Apply direct pressure and nasal packing for bleeding control
Perform rapid sequence intubation with video laryngoscopy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with clinical features of a Le Fort II fracture and has multiple red flags for difficult airway, including oropharyngeal bleeding, facial swelling, and distorted anatomy. Declining oxygen saturation combined with gurgling respirations and inability to clear secretions indicates impending airway compromise. According to ATLS protocol, patients with facial fractures and these red flags require preparation for surgical airway management to avoid a cannot intubate, cannot ventilate scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

While hemostatic control is important and helps improve airway visualization by reducing blood and secretions, this patient has multiple red flags for difficult airway, requiring preparation for surgical intervention. Bleeding control alone does not treat the underlying anatomical distortion nor the airway compromise from facial swelling and structural damage.

C) INCORRECT:

Rapid sequence intubation in a patient with multiple red flags for difficult airway significantly raises the risk of a cannot intubate, cannot ventilate scenario. Conventional intubation without surgical airway preparation is high risk in patients with oropharyngeal bleeding, facial swelling, and distorted anatomy due to midfacial fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

A supraglottic airway device does not provide definitive airway protection in a patient with active oropharyngeal bleeding and secretions. This intervention may be insufficient, depending on the degree of airway compromise, and does not treat the underlying anatomical distortion.

E) INCORRECT:

High-flow nasal cannula oxygen does not treat airway obstruction or inability to clear secretions, which are the priorities in management. This patient requires definitive airway management rather than supplemental oxygenation alone.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents after a motor vehicle collision with facial trauma. She has epistaxis and nasal bridge swelling, and complains of numbness over her right cheek extending to her upper lip. Physical examination shows a palpable step-off deformity at the right inferior orbital rim and slight mobility of her maxilla when the upper teeth are grasped and moved. Extraocular movements are intact bilaterally. What type of facial fracture is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Le Fort I fractures cause floating palate with mobility of the maxillary alveolar ridge and hard palate. These fractures do not typically involve the orbital rim or cause infraorbital nerve anesthesia, as the fracture line runs horizontally below the orbital floor.

B) INCORRECT:

Isolated zygomatic arch fractures do not cause maxillary mobility, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, or step-off deformity at the orbital rim. These fractures typically manifest with impaired mastication due to temporalis muscle impingement.

C) INCORRECT:

An isolated nasal bone fracture does not cause infraorbital nerve anesthesia, palpable step-off at the orbital rim, or maxillary mobility. These findings indicate involvement of multiple facial bones.

D) INCORRECT:

Le Fort III fractures cause craniofacial dissociation with extensive orbital involvement. These fractures typically manifest with bilateral periorbital swelling, enophthalmos, and ophthalmoplegia due to extraocular muscle entrapment, none of which are present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic features of a Le Fort II fracture, which involves nasal bones and inferior orbital floors (causing the palpable step-off), and results in a floating maxilla. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia is caused by fractures involving the infraorbital foramen, which is the most commonly injured cranial nerve in midfacial fractures.
